newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Canberra lifts uranium supply ban with France.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Canberra lifts uranium supply ban with France.

text.p: Australian Deputy Prime Minister and Acting Foreign Affairs Minsiter Tim Fischer said on Monday the government had lifted the ban on new uranium supply contracts with France.

"The government has decided to lift the ban on new uranium supply contracts with France in the light of French signature of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) on September 24," Fischer said in a statement.
The ban on new uranium contracts was imposed in 1988 when France continued to carry out nuclear tests in the Pacific.

"France's support for the treaty (CTBT) outlawing nuclear testing for all time reinforces other actions taken, since its announcement of a 'definitive end to nuclear testing' on January 29, which demonstrate a commitment to nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament objectives," Fischer said. This included the closure of test sites and the signature of protocols to the South Pacific Nuclear weapons free zone treaty, he said.
France has emerged as one of the world's biggest markets for uranium after the country embraced nuclear power generation following the oil shocks of the 1970s.
Energy Resources of Australia Ltd managing director Phil Shirvington has said Electricite de France, the national power company, is the world's single largest buyer of uranium.
Fischer said the decision would be good news for the future of uranium mining at the Roxby Downs mine, owned by WMC Ltd, and the Ranger mine, owned by Energy Resources of Australia.
